poem:
Title: Wind, Deals and Morning Tea

In the cold economic dawn,
Tesco whispers relief, with a side-glance,
as China counters in adverse belief,
navigating the seas of market romance.

Crisp notes rustle like leaves in the wind,
nostalgic for the dance of the free.
Under the weight of a turbine's spin,
even the dragon stirs its morning tea.

Unseen gears tick like a cosmic clock,
but who are we to infer the time?
Echoing the rhythm, we merely mock,
lost in the forest of the economic sublime.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Inflationary pressures have ‘lessened substantially’, says Tesco; Fitch downgrades China’s outlook to negative – business live 10.48am BST China attacks EU "protectionism" over wind subsidy probe Looking back at China… Beijing has criticised the European Union for launching a subsidy investigation into Chinese wind turbine companies. China’s foreign ministry spokesperson Mao Ning told reporters today: “The outside world is worried about the rising tendency of protectionism in the EU,” “China is highly concerned about the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
